captions.text: You just gonna sleep here all day?
You ready to get up yet?

Today we've got some duck meatballs, goose mealballs, and a little bit of salmon, and a little bit of tilapia.  Hey dude relax.  Chill out. Wait until I give it to you. No.  Ok.  Well apparently he is going to eat whatever he wants first today.
thats not how this is supposed to work, little MacGyver man.
You want some goose?  A Gooseball.
Not to be confused with a Goofball, which is what you are sometimes.
How about if I put a little bit of fish on the gooseball.
Here. now its a fish gooseball.
You are one picky bastard.  Ok, here.  You can have the tilapia.
I'm not gonna take it back dude, I already gave it to you.
You munch that stuff down fast, don't you?
What are you doing under here, little MacGyver Man?
You taking a nap under the ottoman? Lazy boy.  You lazy boy.
Don't be greedy, share MacGyver with your friends.

comments.author: Тригада ТиТаСо

comments.text:
How expensive is his diet? would someone with a low wage but lots of care 
be able to afford a beast like this?﻿
comments.author: Phcokiller

comments.text:
+Phcokiller We tend to feed him more expensive foods than the average 
keeper, because we give him lots of fish/shrimp/etc.. I think at the height 
of his growth spurts, his diet was costing us about $100 a month. Now that 
he is full grown and eating less, i think its probably about $40 a month. 
Its possible to do it for less though, and there are some good guides on 
the popular tegu websites sites for healthy lower cost diets.
comments.author: MacGyver the Lizard

comments.text: Macgyver is so cute﻿
comments.author: jamieweber77

comments.text:
Do you walk him to "relive' him? Or does he use something like a "litter 
box"? I'm just curious. MacGyver is so amazing. And I'm glad people like 
you exist, trying to educate others on the real responsibility of pet 
ownership.  ﻿
comments.author: Victoria Good

comments.text: Luckiest boy ever!
comments.author: Victoria Good

comments.text:
Now that we are living in San Diego where the weather is nice almost every 
day, we let him out in the front yard in the morning to get sun, and he 
will do his business in the grass after a few hours before coming back in 
the house by himself through his doggy door.  Back when this video was 
filmed, we were still living in New Jersey where we could only let him 
outside a few months of the year, so the rest of the time he would go to 
the bathroom on the tile floor right after getting out of the bath, and 
we'd just wipe it up with a few paper towels and some 409.
comments.author: MacGyver the Lizard

Not in this video, but he is full grown in the "A day in the life of

comments.author: Robin Locksly

comments.text:
No worries.  Yeah, we give him at least one bath a day to keep him clean. 
 Sometimes when he is shedding we'll give him a second really long bath at 
night and he'll just fall asleep in there for a few hours soaking.
comments.author: MacGyver the Lizard

comments.text:
That's pretty cute :). Do you have to bathe him at all? ((sorry if I'm 
asking too many questions, I just tend to get really curious about stuff))
comments.author: Robin Locksly

comments.text:
He spends most of the time hanging out in the living room, either basking 
in his corner, sleeping under the ottoman, or sleeping on the couch.  He 
does walk around the house though and hang out in other rooms sometimes, 
usually the kitchen where he likes to try and dig under the cabinets.
comments.author: MacGyver the Lizard

comments.text: Cool. Does he have his own area to chill out in?
comments.author: Robin Locksly

comments.text:
Now that he's full grown we only feed him about every other day.  When he 
was a baby though he would eat multiple days a day.
comments.author: MacGyver the Lizard

comments.text:
That's so awesome. If didn't already have three snakes and two dogs at home 
I would totally get a tegu. Out of curiosity, how often do you feed him?
comments.author: Robin Locksly

comments.text:
No enclosure, but we have a corner of the living room setup w/basking 
lights and humidifiers for him

comments.author: njm4088

comments.text: It worked, thanks!
comments.author: Giraffatitan brancai

comments.text:
Yeah I think the shells are fine. We give Mac about 1 eggshell / day 
usually. The only thing I really worry about is the tegu biting down on it 
to quickly and cutting its mouth on a big sharp piece, so I just take the 
whole shell and completely crush it in into a small ball first. The shells 
we give Mac are from raw eggs, so they still have a little egg yolk on em 
which is why I think mac likes em so much.. so u might wanna try rubbing a 
little of the boiled egg on the shell after crushed.
comments.author: MacGyver the Lizard

comments.text:
I've been feeding my 6 month old female hard boiled egg whites with calcium 
powder, would she be alright eating some shell still on the egg? I'm trying 
to figure out how to get her to eat the shell but shes really not up for 
it.
comments.author: Giraffatitan brancai

comments.text: why do u lotion him?
comments.author: Bryn .Layer

comments.text:
could you tell me in a dm or on here what and how much you feed him for the 
week and how much he ate as a juvenile for the week
comments.author: mrhollywood233

comments.text:
1) He gets most of his calcium from whole prey items (currently medium 
rats, day old chicks & quail), and from eggshells. Any time we use an egg 
we pretty much give him the shell. 2) Now that hes so big, blocking off 
places isn't as important, but when he was smaller, blocking off under the 
couch, between cabinets/appliances, and under doors was key. 3) We are 
kinda hermits and don't really leave much. We did take him w/us when we 
evacuated for hurricane Sandy though.
comments.author: MacGyver the Lizard

comments.text: New Jersey
comments.author: MacGyver the Lizard

comments.author: Valentene Peinhardt

comments.text: I've never seen anyone put lotion on their tegu! Why you do that?
comments.author: Valentene Peinhardt

comments.text:
I think the reds get a little bulkier than most black and whites, but 
pretty much same length. There are some subsets of the black and whites 
though (Chacoan white-heads) that can get a lot bigger than the reds. Do a 
search for "Midgard Tegu"... hes a chacoan who is about about 35 lb and I 
think close to 5ft
comments.author: MacGyver the Lizard

comments.text:
Nah, almost everything is raw. We do hard boil eggs for him, but thats 
about it. A few times we have given him some cooked seafood just because we 
had it cooked already for ourselves, but not anything regularly (one time 
we had some cooked king crab legs and we gave him one... and I think we've 
given him steamed/boiled shrimp once or twice because we didn't finish them)
comments.author: MacGyver the Lizard

comments.text: Do you cook his food? I feel dumb asking this haha
comments.author: ohwhythefucknot

comments.text:
He's an Argentine red tegu. Males get up to 4.5 ft and about 20ish lb. In 
this video is only 42 inches and 8 lb, but now he is about 50 inches and 15 
lb (check out more recent videos)

we can gently pick him up and walk around the house with him and he won't

comments.text:
I've never heard of putting lotion on a reptile...Is the lotion you use on 
him specifically made for reptiles?
comments.author: monkoo20

comments.text:
We usually use Palmer's Cocoa butter w/Vitamin E formula after his nightly 
bath to help him shed, especially during the winter when its more dry here. 
Now that its summer and very humid though we're doing it less (maybe once a 
week)
comments.author: MacGyver the Lizard

comments.text:
He's an Argentine red tegu. He is multiple generations captive bred by a 
top notch lizard breeder down in Florida. He's not a komodo, but people 
sometimes ask that when we take him outside for walks on his leash =)
comments.author: MacGyver the Lizard

comments.text:
I think its about $50/month, but its hard to say because we buy lots of 
different foods for him (some in bulk) at different times, and most of the 
seafood/fish we buy in family size packs for both ourselves and for him.
comments.author: MacGyver the Lizard
